p: In addition to medical applications, A. conyzoides also possesses more or less superstitious and mystical aspects. For example, it is believed in Ivory Coast that the plant shields devotees of a snake sect from snakebite and also from bad spirits and demons if used in combination with other plants. In Yoruba, it is used to placate witches; in Gabon, it is used as a part of sophisticated sorcery [ 47]; and in Congo, leaf sap on hands is supposed to bring good luck to card players. Moreover, it is a common perception there that, when rubbed with sap and pricked with a needle on the hand, the accused will feel a pain only if they are guilty [ 16].
